column1: Been with 02 since 2012.Signal was great same with 5g roll out  very rarely have zero signal. Data tracking is very easy on the o2 app. Overall as a company not bad unless you need to speak to customer service. Long time loyalty not rewarded. A friend who's been with 3 5 years gets deals for loyalty a friend on Vodafone gets great loyalty deals for renewing too.  O2 have pushed prices up and up and with annual contract price rises over their new 4 year contracts the showed for black Friday deals was far more than the 36 month currently Overall factoring total price of phone etc. It's almost like o2 currently are actively trying to get customers to leave. Prices are more than other providers and longer. 12 months to go then will be free of 02. The customer service team in the last 18 months have been appalling at best. Contacted them to pay off a contract when was made redundant and got told I don't owe anything again affirmed why and what I wanted to do to be told same again. Was unsuccessful. Sure that's borderline illegal to refuse to allow someone to pay off a contract in full when they have been made redundant and want to pay full balance.

over 2 weeks for customer service to get back to me .want an upgrade to a new phone , and want to stay with 02 , but 02 want ¬£54 pound , another company can give me the phone i want with an 02 contract for ¬£43 plus a ¬£150 cash back .02 will not match , they are the same company .So thank you o2 for wanting to overcharge existing customers .i do have to say Laura at 02 customer service , wow great service , thank you , so now 3 stars instead of one , but if they helped in the first place we wouldnt of had to write a review

I am, as I start to write, hanging on to the 02 customer service, having spent hours going around in circles through the menus on their website trying to cancel a Disney+ add-on that I've never been able to access and am now being charged for.However, eventually Rohit restored my faith by sorting the cancellation and giving me a better phone deal.I give 1 star to the frustrating website but 5 stars to Rohit.

To cut this saga short my number was 'transferred' from my previous mobile airtime supplier.only not all of the relevant files were transferred to O2.After my number was 'transferred' I found that I could only ring out to anyone but initially no one could call me.Eventually we established that only a person using an O2 sim could call me but  no one else.No one at O2 was able to help resolve the problem.I have updated this review as I received a call from O2 explaining what had happened.My old number is now working with my new telephone company.

OK, but not great. Query about changing pin code for sim card resulted in ‚Äòplease go to o2 shop‚Äô. Quite difficult (language problems) to have a meaningful conversation with o2 agent.

Service is normally decent but the overall performance of the network has declined so badly over the years. They do allow 25GB of roaming in EU so that helps. Prices aren‚Äôt as competitive as they used to be.

O2 is just okay-ish. I have been with them, SIM Only customer, for 2 years but I decided to port away to another network after getting tired of not being able to properly use mobile data when I'm out and about.It's okay for general web-browsing but anything more data-heavy in most locations and it will struggle a lot compared to the other networks. 5G on O2 is often slower than 4G, or even 3G, elsewhere.Coverage is its strength and is on par with the leader EE and in some places will beat it. The service options available, like VoLTE, VoWifi, eSim, etc. are quite similar to the competition but the implementation can sometimes seem a bit shaky.O2 Priority is probably the best reward system alongside Vodafone Very Me but it's hardly a thing I can't live without.Offers good value for money, if comparison or cashback sites are used, and it's the only main network that has EU roaming included on all plans and with a generous 25GB limit. The Volt benefits, double data and free roaming in extra locations is a nice extra.My experience with Customer Service has been sporadic but has been between okay and good, apart from one time when I couldn't correctly contact them for a whole weekend about a billing issue.If you are looking for a network for calls, texts and basic data it can be a good choice. If you need something more on the data-side then look elsewhere.

Out of the 3 mobile numbers registered on Virgin Family plan 1 number was transferred to O2 and is visible on MyO2 app and the other 2 numbers were transferred to O2 but are parked somewhere on the system. They explained how to set up alternative account for my other 2 numbers and couldn‚Äôt have been more helpful and knowledgeable and managed to persuade me to stay with O2 for another 12 months by taking a third off my bill.  Maybe Virgin have access to better level of O2 customer service because whenever I phoned O2 directly I ended up speaking to somebody in overseas call centers with poor English and wrong attitude.Anyway, my overall rating is 3 stars: I did get what I wanted (access to other 2 numbers and reduced contract cost) but customer service is very poor and transfer from Virgin to O2 was crap.

My overall experience with O2 has been mixed. There is no other way to describe it.Let's start off with the positives.I have what I would call an unbeatable deal from O2 thanks to the Virgin Mobile migration. My phone bill is ¬£6.79/mo for completely unlimited data (on VM, it was for 2GB, plan price was originally 2GB for a 12 month contract in 08/2018), which no other network would ever be able to beat. I currently use around 40GB in a month, which is a stark contrast to never using over 4GB in a month for 5 years. Granted my usage habits have changed now that I'm free to burn my data.Through the Virgin Mobile migration, I also gained the ability to use 4G calling and WiFi calling (yes Virgin did have the ability for both, but it just would have been a pain to set up) from the moment I migrated. Unfortunately, these features did disappear for a long time (from about July to mid-December) which sucks. I don't make calls often but both options make calls crystal clear and reliable.A bit after mid-November, I decided to get a SIM swap with O2, since I was still using my old Virgin SIM (which was originally programmed to connect to the EE network, still have remnants of that even with my new O2 SIM with the T-Mobile MNC seemingly reporting "Virgin Mobile" when manually searching for networks). The SIM swap processed extremely quickly with being delivered within just 2 days (one day after my order confirmation), which was a stark contrast from the experience that I had with moving someone from Plusnet to EE (SIM took 4 days to deliver and EE didn't even send confirmation details).Priority is a cool plus to have and getting Volt features is nice too.Now the negatives.With the migration, I was promised the visual voicemail feature on my Android phone, but it has yet to work for me. I've had a tab for it appear once, but that's it.On Virgin, RCS always worked perfectly fine. Meanwhile on O2, I've had a few problems (particularly by the migration from O2's RCS to Jibe RCS) and it's left me unable to use RCS.I'd like to finally end this off with a concern I have for the future as an O2 customer. Due to the way that O2 migrated Virgin customers, my tariff price is ¬£13.29 with a ¬£6.50 discount bolt-on. I am concerned that the annual price increases will cost more on O2 than it would of on Virgin due to the way that the migration was handled.

As of the time of writing this review, one of our contracts has been canceled, and we're hoping it stays that way. Prior to this, my family had three contracts: one for myself, one for my dad, and one for my little brother. My dad and I had a generally positive experience with our contracts, with only occasional internet signal issues, which were infrequent and didn't significantly affect our overall satisfaction.Now, let's delve into the canceled contract concerning my little brother. Approximately two months ago, he temporarily lost his phone, but he managed to retrieve it the following day. On the day the phone was lost, we promptly contacted the service provider to report it and have the number barred. We were informed that we'd need to wait for 24 hours for the bar to be lifted, which we accepted. However, for the following three days, my brother couldn't make calls or use data. We reached out to customer support, only to be advised that switching SIM cards would be quicker. We visited the first store in Wembley, but my brother failed to answer the security questions and lacked the required identification, which, understandably, the store couldn't overlook.We then tried another store in Edgware while I was taking care of my car. We brought two forms of ID and proof of billing, and requested a new SIM card. However, we faced the same issue with security questions and ID verification. The system seemed to have a glitch in specifying which security question to answer. We contacted the service provider, and it turned out that my brother had two security questions and answers, and the system wasn't clear on which one to use. Despite answering correctly, the issue persisted.After trying to resolve the problem for several days, including obtaining multiple SIM cards and switching to different phones, we realized the problem wasn't with the SIM but likely linked to my brother's account. The service provider promised to investigate, but after a week, they requested another week to continue their inquiry. Keep in mind that we made repeated calls during this process, and sometimes the support team didn't have the necessary information, forcing us to provide it repeatedly.After waiting for over a month and a half with no resolution in sight, we decided to cancel the contract. Fortunately, we were given credit, so we didn't have to pay, but it became apparent that having a contract was pointless if we couldn't use the SIM. Interestingly, we switched to Giffgaff, which operates on the same network as our previous provider (O2), using the PAC code for our number, and everything worked perfectly. As such, I don't expect a cancellation bill, as I left the contract due to the absence of service, which should be evident in their records. It appears that my account was disabled at the time of writing this review.
